LayoutNode.Content: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Ltd., trading as Foxconn Technology Group, is a Taiwanese multinational electronics contract manufacturing company headquartered in Tucheng, New Taipei, Taiwan. It is the world's largest electronics contracter manufacturer, and the third-largest information technology company by revenue.
LayoutNode.SRC: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Ltd., trading as Foxconn Technology Group, is a Taiwanese multinational electronics contract manufacturing company headquartered in Tucheng, New Taipei, Taiwan. It is the world's largest electronics contracter manufacturer, and the third-largest information technology company by revenue.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn is primarily an original design manufacturer and its clients include major American, European, and Japanese electronics and information technology companies. Notable products that the company manufactures include the BlackBerry, iPad, iPhone, iPod, Kindle, Xbox One, Xbox 360, PlayStation 3, Playstation 4, Wii, and Wii U.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn is primarily an original design manufacturer and its clients include major American, European, and Japanese electronics and information technology companies. Notable products that the company manufactures include the BlackBerry, iPad, iPhone, iPod, Kindle, Xbox One, Xbox 360, PlayStation 3, Playstation 4, Wii, and Wii U.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn has been involved in several controversies relating to how it manages employees in China, although reports are to some extent conflicting.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn has been involved in several controversies relating to how it manages employees in China, although reports are to some extent conflicting.

LayoutNode.Content: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Ltd. was founded in 1974 by Terry Guo as a manufacturer of electrical components (notably electrical connectors for computer components, which found use in the Atari 2600). Foxconn was originally a trade name of Hon Hai and a subsidiary later received the name. Hon Hai's first manufacturing plant in mainland China opened in Longhua, Shenzhen, in 1988.
LayoutNode.SRC: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Ltd. was founded in 1974 by Terry Guo as a manufacturer of electrical components (notably electrical connectors for computer components, which found use in the Atari 2600). Foxconn was originally a trade name of Hon Hai and a subsidiary later received the name. Hon Hai's first manufacturing plant in mainland China opened in Longhua, Shenzhen, in 1988.

LayoutNode.Content: In 2001 Intel concentrated on its core competency of chip making and began using Chinese contract manufacturers such as Foxconn to make Intel-branded motherboards.
LayoutNode.SRC: In 2001 Intel concentrated on its core competency of chip making and began using Chinese contract manufacturers such as Foxconn to make Intel-branded motherboards.

LayoutNode.Content: In November 2007 Foxconn announced plans to build a new US$500 million plant in Huizhou, Southern China.
LayoutNode.SRC: In November 2007 Foxconn announced plans to build a new US$500 million plant in Huizhou, Southern China.

LayoutNode.Content: In March 2012 Foxconn agreed to acquire a 10 percent stake in the Japanese electronics company Sharp Corporation for US$806 million and to purchase up to 50 percent of the LCD displays produced at Sharp's plant in Sakai, Japan.
LayoutNode.SRC: In March 2012 Foxconn agreed to acquire a 10 percent stake in the Japanese electronics company Sharp Corporation for US$806 million and to purchase up to 50 percent of the LCD displays produced at Sharp's plant in Sakai, Japan.

LayoutNode.Content: In January 2012 Foxconn named Tien Chong (Terry) Cheng chief executive, who soon resigned, citing health problems.
LayoutNode.SRC: In January 2012 Foxconn named Tien Chong (Terry) Cheng chief executive, who soon resigned, citing health problems.

LayoutNode.Content: In September 2012 Foxconn announced plans to invest US$494 million in the construction of five new factories in Itu, Brazil, creating 10,000 jobs.
LayoutNode.SRC: In September 2012 Foxconn announced plans to invest US$494 million in the construction of five new factories in Itu, Brazil, creating 10,000 jobs.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn has factories in Asia, Europe, Mexico and South America that together assemble around 40 percent of all consumer electronics products sold.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn has factories in Asia, Europe, Mexico and South America that together assemble around 40 percent of all consumer electronics products sold.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn has 13 factories in nine Chinese cities—more than in any other country.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn has 13 factories in nine Chinese cities—more than in any other country.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn's largest factory worldwide is in Longhua, Shenzhen, where hundreds of thousands of workers (varying counts include 230,000, 300,000, and 450,000) are employed at the Longhua Science & Technology Park, a walled campus sometimes referred to as "Foxconn City" or "iPod City". Covering about 1.16 square miles (3 square km), it includes 15 factories, worker dormitories, a swimming pool, a fire brigade, its own television network (Foxconn TV), and a city centre with a grocery store, bank, restaurants, bookstore, and hospital. While some workers live in surrounding towns and villages, others live and work inside the complex; a quarter of the employees live in the dormitories, and many of them work up to 12 hours a day for 6 days each week. Another of Foxconn's factory "cities" is Zhengzhou Technology Park in Zhengzhou, Henan province, where it is reported 120,000 employees work.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn's largest factory worldwide is in Longhua, Shenzhen, where hundreds of thousands of workers (varying counts include 230,000, 300,000, and 450,000) are employed at the Longhua Science & Technology Park, a walled campus sometimes referred to as "Foxconn City" or "iPod City". Covering about 1.16 square miles (3 square km), it includes 15 factories, worker dormitories, a swimming pool, a fire brigade, its own television network (Foxconn TV), and a city centre with a grocery store, bank, restaurants, bookstore, and hospital. While some workers live in surrounding towns and villages, others live and work inside the complex; a quarter of the employees live in the dormitories, and many of them work up to 12 hours a day for 6 days each week. Another of Foxconn's factory "cities" is Zhengzhou Technology Park in Zhengzhou, Henan province, where it is reported 120,000 employees work.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn continues to expand, and planned factories include sites at Chengdu in Sichuan province and Wuhan in Hubei province.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn continues to expand, and planned factories include sites at Chengdu in Sichuan province and Wuhan in Hubei province.

LayoutNode.Content: All company facilities in South America are located in Brazil, and these include mobile phone factories in Manaus and Indaiatuba as well as production bases in Jundiai, Sorocaba, and Santa Rita do Sapucaí. The company is considering more investments in Brazil.
LayoutNode.SRC: All company facilities in South America are located in Brazil, and these include mobile phone factories in Manaus and Indaiatuba as well as production bases in Jundiai, Sorocaba, and Santa Rita do Sapucaí. The company is considering more investments in Brazil.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn has factories in Hungary, Slovakia, and the Czech Republic. It is the second-largest exporter in the Czech Republic.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn has factories in Hungary, Slovakia, and the Czech Republic. It is the second-largest exporter in the Czech Republic.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn has operational units in the Special Economic Zone of Chennai, Tamil Nadu.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn has operational units in the Special Economic Zone of Chennai, Tamil Nadu.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn and Sharp Corporation jointly run two plants manufacturing large-screen televisions in Sakai, Osaka. In August 2012 it was reported that Sharp, while doing corporate restructuring and downsizing, was considering selling the plants to Foxconn, which was believed to be receptive to the plan.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn and Sharp Corporation jointly run two plants manufacturing large-screen televisions in Sakai, Osaka. In August 2012 it was reported that Sharp, while doing corporate restructuring and downsizing, was considering selling the plants to Foxconn, which was believed to be receptive to the plan.

LayoutNode.Content: As of 2011, Foxconn had at least seven factories in Johor state, possibly at Kulaijaya, where it is developing an industrial park that will include four factories once completed.
LayoutNode.SRC: As of 2011, Foxconn had at least seven factories in Johor state, possibly at Kulaijaya, where it is developing an industrial park that will include four factories once completed.

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn has a facility in San Jerónimo, Chihuahua that assembles computers, and two facilities in Juárez – a former Motorola production base that manufactures mobile phones, and a set-top box factory acquired from Cisco Systems. LCD televisions are also made in the country by Foxconn in a plant acquired from Sony.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn has a facility in San Jerónimo, Chihuahua that assembles computers, and two facilities in Juárez – a former Motorola production base that manufactures mobile phones, and a set-top box factory acquired from Cisco Systems. LCD televisions are also made in the country by Foxconn in a plant acquired from Sony.

LayoutNode.Content: In December 2013, Foxconn announced plans to invest $30 million over two years to build a manufacturing facility in Pennsylvania, as well as putting $10 million into R&D at Carnegie Mellon University. The new facility will be located in Harrisburg and will develop robotic equipment.
LayoutNode.SRC: In December 2013, Foxconn announced plans to invest $30 million over two years to build a manufacturing facility in Pennsylvania, as well as putting $10 million into R&D at Carnegie Mellon University. The new facility will be located in Harrisburg and will develop robotic equipment.

LayoutNode.SRC: Major customers of Foxconn include or have included:

LayoutNode.Content: Apple has stated that it contracts with Chinese original equipment manufacturers such as Foxconn because they have easy access to the Chinese supply chain within a well developed industrial cluster.
LayoutNode.SRC: Apple has stated that it contracts with Chinese original equipment manufacturers such as Foxconn because they have easy access to the Chinese supply chain within a well developed industrial cluster.

LayoutNode.Content: Allegations of poor working conditions have been made on several occasions. News reports highlight the long working hours, discrimination against mainland Chinese workers by their Taiwanese co-workers, and lack of working relationships at the company. Although Foxconn was found to be compliant in the majority of areas when Apple Inc. audited the maker of its iPods and iPhones in 2007 the audit did substantiate a few of the allegations.
LayoutNode.SRC: Allegations of poor working conditions have been made on several occasions. News reports highlight the long working hours, discrimination against mainland Chinese workers by their Taiwanese co-workers, and lack of working relationships at the company. Although Foxconn was found to be compliant in the majority of areas when Apple Inc. audited the maker of its iPods and iPhones in 2007 the audit did substantiate a few of the allegations.

LayoutNode.Content: Concerns increased in early 2012 due to a US theatrical monologue purportedly based on factual accounts of working conditions at Foxconn, but much of the source material was later found to be fictional. However, a 2012 audit performed by the Fair Labor Association at the request of Apple Inc. found that workers routinely received insufficient overtime pay and suggested that workplace accidents may be common.
LayoutNode.SRC: Concerns increased in early 2012 due to a US theatrical monologue purportedly based on factual accounts of working conditions at Foxconn, but much of the source material was later found to be fictional. However, a 2012 audit performed by the Fair Labor Association at the request of Apple Inc. found that workers routinely received insufficient overtime pay and suggested that workplace accidents may be common.

LayoutNode.Content: A Hong Kong non-profit organisation, Students and Scholars Against Corporate Misbehavior, has written numerous negative reports on Foxconn's treatment of its employees. These typically find far worse conditions than the 2012 Fair Labor Association audit did but rely on a far smaller number of employee informants–100 to 170. The Fair Labor Association audit in 2012 used interviews with 35,000 Foxconn employees.
LayoutNode.SRC: A Hong Kong non-profit organisation, Students and Scholars Against Corporate Misbehavior, has written numerous negative reports on Foxconn's treatment of its employees. These typically find far worse conditions than the 2012 Fair Labor Association audit did but rely on a far smaller number of employee informants–100 to 170. The Fair Labor Association audit in 2012 used interviews with 35,000 Foxconn employees.

LayoutNode.Content: In September 2012 a fight at worker dormitories in Taiyuan, Shanxi, escalated into a riot involving 2000 people and was quelled by security.
LayoutNode.SRC: In September 2012 a fight at worker dormitories in Taiyuan, Shanxi, escalated into a riot involving 2000 people and was quelled by security.

LayoutNode.Content: In October 2012, the company admitted that 14-year-old children had worked for a short time at a facility in Yantai, Shandong Province. Foxconn said that the workers involved were part of an internship program. Individuals as young as 16 can legally work in China.
LayoutNode.SRC: In October 2012, the company admitted that 14-year-old children had worked for a short time at a facility in Yantai, Shandong Province. Foxconn said that the workers involved were part of an internship program. Individuals as young as 16 can legally work in China.

LayoutNode.Content: Also in October 2012 a young worker, Zhang Tingzhen, was threatened to have Hon-Hal medical support canceled, when doctors remonstrated against moving his injured body for treatment in Huizhou from the hospital in Shenzhen. He suffered an electrical shock and was injured to the extent that doctors needed to amputate half of his brain. This left him in no condition to travel to Huizhou, the city he was initially hired at. The company stated that it was acting within labor laws.
LayoutNode.SRC: Also in October 2012 a young worker, Zhang Tingzhen, was threatened to have Hon-Hal medical support canceled, when doctors remonstrated against moving his injured body for treatment in Huizhou from the hospital in Shenzhen. He suffered an electrical shock and was injured to the extent that doctors needed to amputate half of his brain. This left him in no condition to travel to Huizhou, the city he was initially hired at. The company stated that it was acting within labor laws.

LayoutNode.Content: Children have been spotted entering and leaving the Foxconn factory in China where Apple iPhones are made. The Guardian posted that 'Apple has discovered multiple cases of child labour in its supply chain, including one Chinese company that employed 74 children under the age of 16, in the latest controversy over the technology giant's manufacturing methods.' in Jan, 2013. [1] Similar articles on CNET as well that The company has issued a statement saying that it performed an internal investigation at its Yantai facility in the Shandong Province, and found that some of the interns working there ranged in age from 14 to 16 years old. China's legal working age is 16. [2]2012-10-16
LayoutNode.SRC: Children have been spotted entering and leaving the Foxconn factory in China where Apple iPhones are made. The Guardian posted that 'Apple has discovered multiple cases of child labour in its supply chain, including one Chinese company that employed 74 children under the age of 16, in the latest controversy over the technology giant's manufacturing methods.' in Jan, 2013. [1] Similar articles on CNET as well that The company has issued a statement saying that it performed an internal investigation at its Yantai facility in the Shandong Province, and found that some of the interns working there ranged in age from 14 to 16 years old. China's legal working age is 16. [2]2012-10-16

LayoutNode.Content: Renowned US performer Mike Daisey has travelled to China, and says he spoke with workers at the gates of Foxconn, including one very young looking woman. After chatting he knew that the girl is only 13 years old and the girl said the factory didn't check the age and they just pull everyone from the affected line, and then they put the oldest workers they have on that line. In Daisey's report, which you can hear in its entirety below, he says that the young woman said she was employed to wipe iPhone screens. "[Huffpost tech]" [3] 2012-02-17
LayoutNode.SRC: Renowned US performer Mike Daisey has travelled to China, and says he spoke with workers at the gates of Foxconn, including one very young looking woman. After chatting he knew that the girl is only 13 years old and the girl said the factory didn't check the age and they just pull everyone from the affected line, and then they put the oldest workers they have on that line. In Daisey's report, which you can hear in its entirety below, he says that the young woman said she was employed to wipe iPhone screens. "[Huffpost tech]" [3] 2012-02-17

LayoutNode.Content: Foxconn actually has already violated the rules from the List of International Labour Organization Conventions. And Foxconn has been monitored by the International Labour Organization for hiring children labour as well as the low working conditions.
LayoutNode.SRC: Foxconn actually has already violated the rules from the List of International Labour Organization Conventions. And Foxconn has been monitored by the International Labour Organization for hiring children labour as well as the low working conditions.
Main article: Foxconn suicides

LayoutNode.Content: Suicides among Foxconn workers have attracted media attention. One was the high-profile death of a worker after the loss of a prototype and the other, a series of suicides linked to low pay in 2010. Suicides of Foxconn workers continued into 2012, with one in June 2012. The rate has substantially fallen since 2010.
LayoutNode.SRC: Suicides among Foxconn workers have attracted media attention. One was the high-profile death of a worker after the loss of a prototype and the other, a series of suicides linked to low pay in 2010. Suicides of Foxconn workers continued into 2012, with one in June 2012. The rate has substantially fallen since 2010.

LayoutNode.Content: Sun Danyong, a 25-year-old man, committed suicide in July 2009 after reporting the loss of an iPhone 4 prototype in his possession.
LayoutNode.SRC: Sun Danyong, a 25-year-old man, committed suicide in July 2009 after reporting the loss of an iPhone 4 prototype in his possession.

LayoutNode.Content: In reaction to a spate of worker suicides in which 14 people died in 2010, a report from 20 Chinese universities described Foxconn factories as labor camps and detailed widespread worker abuse and illegal overtime. In response to the suicides, Foxconn installed suicide-prevention netting at some facilities, and it promised to offer substantially higher wages at its Shenzhen production bases. Workers were also forced to sign a legally binding document guaranteeing they and their descendants would not sue the company as a result of unexpected death, self-injury or suicide.
LayoutNode.SRC: In reaction to a spate of worker suicides in which 14 people died in 2010, a report from 20 Chinese universities described Foxconn factories as labor camps and detailed widespread worker abuse and illegal overtime. In response to the suicides, Foxconn installed suicide-prevention netting at some facilities, and it promised to offer substantially higher wages at its Shenzhen production bases. Workers were also forced to sign a legally binding document guaranteeing they and their descendants would not sue the company as a result of unexpected death, self-injury or suicide.

LayoutNode.Content: Against this, the suicide rate at Foxconn, even during the suicide spate, was lower than that of China as well as that of all 50 states of the United States.
LayoutNode.SRC: Against this, the suicide rate at Foxconn, even during the suicide spate, was lower than that of China as well as that of all 50 states of the United States.
